Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:2.0.1) Gecko/20110511 SeaMonkey/2.1 (2.1RC1)

When I go to delete a saved password, "Passwords only" shows in the pull-down list at the upper-left corner of the Data Manager window.  If I delete the only password (only one account) for a given URI, the pull-down list reverts to "All data".  This is a recipe for unintentional deletion of other data.  

Reproducible: Always

comments.raw_text:
I followed the test steps in comment #2 with one exception: I did not delete any cookies (skipped step #5).  I did this in a new profile in Safe Mode.  

The result is that, after selecting "Passwords only" and deleting the password for http://www.gmail.com/, Data Manager switched to the Cookies tab.  I again selected "Passwords only" and deleted the password for http://mail.yahoo.com/; again Data Manager switched to the Cookies tab.  

The switching of tabs is sufficiently quick that a user who blinks might not notice.  As I pointed out in the original Description: "This is a recipe for unintentional deletion of other data."

comments.raw_text:
It's actually more general than the title says - it doesn't just apply to passwords.

1.  Select "Preferences only" in Data Manager
2.  Find a domain that has both preferences and some other type of data
3.  Delete the preference(s) for that domain

It still *says* "Preferences only" at the top, but the domain you chose still displays in the list on the left-hand pane, and the right-hand pane displays the tab for whatever non-preference data that domain has.

I haven't tested it, but I suspect this incorrect behaviour probably happens for *any* combination of types of data.  FYI, I'm seeing this on (and yes, I realize this isn't quite current, but it's much newer than in earlier comments on this bug so the problem persists):

Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:11.0) Gecko/20120312 Firefox/11.0 SeaMonkey/2.8
comments.creator: stephen@stevedunn.ca
